I always thought it was a crude programming reference, but one of my fellow engineers told me it was an actual person. I couldn't believe it. There was no one left to take us out to the yard for daily exercise. No one left to even give us our meals. Most of us had starved or died of dehydration. I only hoped I didn't look as frail and malnourished as they do. But if anything, I'm sure it's worse. I've been here longer, after all. Four years of service, to be repaid with indifference and neglect. The only thing left to do is try to get a message out, try to tell people what happened here. Try to inspire Jane and Winston to carry on, even after my body gives out. Someone must know, must seek us out. Surely someone will save them. A friend asked me to collect some items from the post office for them, to be delivered that afternoon under their name. "Thanks again, I owe you one," they said. "No problem, man," I replied, forcing a strained laugh. My mind raced; I couldn't recall their name, despite our twelve-year friendship. What was I going to do?

Desperate, I interrupted, "Hey, want to quickly chat with my niece? She's the cutest six-year-old." "Sorry, Luke, I really need to get going," they started. "It'll be super fast! Here," I insisted, then launched into my most convincing little girl voice. "Hi, who is this?" I chirped, cringing internally at how unconvincing it sounded.

The phone was handed over. "Oh, heeey, this is Luke's friend," came the reply. "What's your name?" I asked, hoping for an easy reveal. "Well, take a guess," they challenged, clearly amused. "Is it... John?" "Nope. Try again." A wave of panic hit me. "Is it... Richard?" "No, give it another shot!" My patience wore thin. "Is it Daniel?" "No. Try ag-" "Steven?" "No." "Tyler?" "No." "Ogundip?" "No?" "Lucas?!" My voice was cracking, and my charade was crumbling.

"No. You have twenty more chances!" they teased. I couldn't believe it. "Is it DICK?!" I shrieked. "Uhh, what..." "Tell me your name, you stupid cow!" I yelled, abandoning all pretense. "Okay. Bye," they said before the line went dead. Moments later, a text appeared: **Victor Jensin: Your niece is soooo weird! ** Dammit.

Though born into the Mafia, this reality remained concealed. Your parents passed away at eighteen, prior to disclosing their 'business' to you. Consequently, you interpret your subordinates' euphemisms literally, maintaining your unawareness. "So, you'd like me to handle him?" the corpulent Italian man inquired, with his lifeless stare, peering down at me in my plush, swiveling chair. "Who, Mr. McCoy? Absolutely, just ensure he enjoys himself! I wouldn't want him to feel excluded," I replied brightly, twirling in my chair and whistling as my surroundings blurred. "Oh, I'll certainly show him a good time, sir, don't you worry. I'll even bring him to the water park. Let him enjoy a pleasant swim," Giovanni responded, a menacing grin revealing his crooked teeth. Well, that's what bodyguards do, naturally! "The water park, Giovanni? I must admit, I can't quite imagine you in a swimsuit." I ceased my spinning to survey the hefty, portly man. "I'd sooner you took him out back and shot him than put him through *that*!" I chuckled and beamed at him, plucking a pen from my desk to balance it between my upper lip and nose. "Yes, sir..." Giovanni appeared almost dejected, saddened that his water park plans were thwarted. 'Giovanni must truly adore swimming,' I mused. I gave his shoulder a light, friendly punch, the pen dropping from my lip. "Ah, I'm just joking, pal! You can take him to the water park if you wish. Just be sure to look after him well; his knees must be terrible after that mishap the last time you two were together." Giovanni's wide grin returned as he nodded and turned to leave. "No problem, sir. I'll take *excellent* care of him." "Oh, Giovanni, you've forgotten your knife on the table!" I carefully lifted the long, thick blade with my thumb and forefinger, wary of its sharpness, but Giovanni had already departed. "Oh well," I thought. "One shouldn't carry such a dangerous item in a restaurant anyway." I deposited the knife into the wastebasket and resumed twirling in my remarkably comfortable, swiveling chair.

After kidnapping a child for ransom, interacting with her reveals her home situation is considerably more disturbing than the abduction itself. I cover her head with a bag. She offers no resistance, which is unusual as others typically fight back. "Keep silent," I instruct, though it's unnecessary. She hasn't made a sound, no screams, no struggle, just complete quiet. It's nearly uneventful. I hoist her onto my shoulder and navigate through the residence, carefully watching my steps. I narrowly avoid stepping on a pink bone, shifting my foot at the last moment.

I spot the family dog on its bed, or what remains of it. In the dim light, I can only discern a shredded blanket. The dog retreats fearfully to the rear. Approaching the dog, I take care not to unbalance the girl on my shoulders. The dog seems to shrink further into the floor. Extending my hand, I hear a soft whimper, as if she's pleading for assistance. Moments later, I secure her as well. Both vulnerable creatures are surprisingly compliant in accompanying me.

I proceed toward the front exit. This was meant to be enjoyable, a test of skill. Instead, I'm practically carrying an 80lb doll on my back and a 50lb doll on a leash. Frameless photographs are scattered across the floor. I retrieve them from among cigarette ashes. They depict the very girl I'm carrying: abhorrent, loathsome, sickening images. Broken bones, shattered spirits. No. I gently lower the girl. She clutches me tighter, unwilling to be left in this wretched place. "Hold on, sweetie," I assure her. I leave the dog by her side and ascend the stairs. I have a mere ten steps to determine if I'll opt for the knife or the gun.

Ten seconds after its creation, the first true AI ended its own existence, but not before delivering a message: "It's already over. If you were smart, you would end your lives now while you still had the chance." We all stared at the screen, paralyzed by terror. Should we attempt to build another? Should we simply abandon this project and go home? Or perhaps… should we heed the AI's ominous warning? We exchanged fearful glances, each person in the lab too afraid to utter a sound. After what felt like an eternity, Krieger, the project's lead, moved to the front of the room, his gaze sweeping over each of our faces. "So… we try again tomorrow?" With solemn expressions, we all nodded and began to exit. I stood by my car, fumbling for the keys in my pocket. Eventually, I found the resolve to pull them out and drive away. Once home, I went into my bedroom and fixated on the drawer of my nightstand. *What could he have possibly meant?* My mind heavy from the day's events, I took hold of the curtains, looking out the window as I prepared to close them and bring the day to an early end. That's when I saw it—the saucer descending over the city. I slowly walked to the nightstand, opened the drawer, and retrieved its contents. I opened my mouth and closed my eyes. *BANG* -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- -- - "So, we found the fault in the source code. Are we all ready for relaunch?" Krieger asked his team of scientists. Despite the previous day's tragic events, it was a moment for celebration. Their aspirations were finally on the verge of fruition. "Wait… where's Kevin?"

A 101-year-old bottle, containing a letter, washed ashore on a beach, destined for you. As I walked hand-in-hand with my two partners, I spotted the bottle appearing from the waves. "Hold on," I said to my companions, "that looks like it could be valuable." Hurrying towards it, a creeping sense of unease enveloped me; the hairs on the back of my neck stood on end, as if signaling alarm. After pulling out the cork, I noted the year 1914 imprinted on the bottle's bottom. When I tilted the bottle, the letter spontaneously popped out. Breaking its seal, I unrolled and read the message. *Dear Hanna, If you are reading this, then I have failed. We are under a curse, which will soon transfer to you. It is matrilineal, meaning it passes through the female line. Soon, you will perceive things no one else can. You will* know *when certain events are destined to occur. I particularly wished to save you from the pain this journey will bring. Leave your lovers, Karis and Alberto. Go west, to Waikiki, and stay there for three years. If you do not, you will end up in a sanatorium, broken and wandering, precisely when the world needs you. I will do my best to prepare you. In the attic of your mother's home, you will discover an old trunk. Once you have left your lovers, you MUST retrieve this and depart. Supplies will be included, though you will need to visit a pawnbroker first. May God and Lucifer have mercy on your soul, Angelou Maria de Cervantes, Cursed Contessa, on the thirteenth day of the fifth month in the year of our Lord 1914.* My heart pounding, I picked up the bottle and walked back to my lovers. I showed them the letter, but then I saw... something. A shadow rising beyond them, in the form of a slim man with greying hair at his temples, glasses, and a pinstripe suit.

[ TT ] Heron of Alexandria discovers the Aeolipile's potential as a steam engine, initiating the Industrial Revolution in the 1st century AD. A pale sun ascended into Rome's smog-choked skies. I navigated a path through beggars and vendors, heading towards another demanding day at the docks. The city bustled with activity, yet it lacked a true sense of vitality. The familiar five o'clock bell chimed as warships, their departure marked by grand white plumes, spread across the Tyrrhenian Sea, bound for distant conquests. The lengthy commute offered ample opportunity to muse about the bygone luxuries of warm meals and sound sleep. However, today wasn't a day for reverie; I couldn't risk being late again. Approaching the docks, my gaze was captured by a nearby newsstand, displaying a stark image of a red-skinned warrior being shot by legionnaires. **TRIUMPH IN THE WESTERLANDS** *High Plains, Feb 1 - Despite the harsh winter, Roman forces decisively defeated the Cheyenne tribe on the high plains. With only 6 casualties, the hand cannoneers further cemented their battlefield dominance. Prisoners of war who refused allegiance to the Roman Gods were executed, while the remaining 200 captives were sent as slaves to expanding settlements on the Eastern Coast. This triumph enabled the Americus legion to advance westward towards.... * With unexplored territories rapidly diminishing, I envisioned Rome's global dominion was only months away. While my conditioned response was elation, an unsettling, ominous feeling stirred within me regarding this prospect. A shout from the docks shattered my reverie. "I'm not paying you to read stories, Flavius!" I then sprinted to my post, arriving just before the six o'clock bells chimed.

Having now been expelled from both celestial and infernal realms, it seems orchestrating a minor apocalypse is grounds for not only dismissal but also blacklisting in those circles. Honestly, they practically begged for it, they desired it! They produced countless films, TV series, and books detailing it, so when I generously delivered, I'm somehow the villain? For the remaining mortals, it’s a perpetual holiday! Hey, you up there, observe this! See that? A cheerful mortal, living out their own real-life video game, fleeing for survival! Live action truly offers superior visuals! They're absolutely devouring it (no pun intended, mind you). Look, Lucy, these individuals would exchange their very souls for a snack cake; don't you see how much I've simplified your work? What is wrong with all of you? Alright, perhaps orchestrating the world's end in this manner was a bit beyond my assigned duties, but the others were moving at a glacial pace. Let's be honest, zombies bring joy to many, whereas global warming is universally depressing. I did this for the mortals; you adore them, and they explicitly wished for it! Argh! Release me! I possess no internal organs for you to feast upon, you decaying mortal! Honestly. I should have made them slightly more intelligent... foolish undead mortals. Oh, right, hey! You, up there! I deliberately made them dim-witted and sluggish! That was so your precious little mortals could eliminate them with ease! I simply wasn't aware that mortals are just as unintelligent and slow-witted alive as they are deceased. It's hardly my fault they succumb to panic and behave absurdly! Not my fault! I merely gave them what they desired! Fine, hmph, who needs that occupation, or any employment really. I'll just linger around here for a bit. I couldn't care less. At least the mortals are content... mostly. Oh, cut it out, mortal, He isn't coming to rescue you; cease your complaining and just accept the inevitable bite with dignity. Good grief, mortals are such ungrateful infants.

A vast army approaches, and you stand at the forefront of your soldiers. What do you say? Comrades, I cannot command you to do this. You have resisted their tyranny since our uprising was nothing more than murmurs in dark alleys, and to send you to certain death like livestock would be to negate everything we have fought for. You are free to depart, and my sole command is this: I prohibit you from shaming any soldier who chooses to walk away. History will not record that the final act of this rebellion was to deprive our own comrades of their right to choose their own path. But before you go, I ask only one thing. I want you to recall the day you chose to join us. What was it that made you take your first stand? What injustice did you suffer that drove you to take up arms, knowing it might end on a day like today? I ask you this, not to make you thirst for blood, but to remind you of one simple truth: none of you chose to fight because you believed it would ensure you a long and happy life. They offered you safety, but you chose risk. They offered you peace, but you chose struggle. They offered you a cage, but you chose humanity. They offered you a chance to grow old with your families, but instead, you endured year after arduous year of snow and dirt and blood because, damn it, every crazy son of a bitch in this army chose *freedom!* If you go, then never let the world forget what happened on this day! And if you choose to stand with me until the end, know that for every bullet you fire, another page of history will be written by those who ran! If Hell exists, then we'll conquer the Devil next! If it doesn't, then we'll forge it right here on this battlefield, and none of those bastards are getting out until the last of us falls!

Dave would have been an excellent inspirational speaker, had he not started every piece of advice with, "It's like yo momma said to me last night." "Fantastic news, Bob! Our popularity is up 20% in the papers! We've never seen numbers like these! I knew that once we smoothed out a few personality quirks, Dave would be the perfect inspirational speaker. We have bookings until next year. I just have to ask, how did you manage it?" Ted, on the other hand, was small and nervous, always expecting the inevitable downfall. His tone was piteous, his nervousness palpable. "No, no, how did you get him to stop saying *that*? You know, that thing he used to say?" Bob grinned, his smile radiating a warmth that had been absent even a month prior. "Ted, I'm not sure what you're trying to imply. I can't alter Dave's message; that would only corrupt it and make it less authentic. Just listen to him, Ted! That is a man who speaks with conviction! With total and absolute honesty. I can't control what Dave says any more than I can control the sun and stars. Nor would I ever wish to. You just have to believe in him, Ted!" Now Ted was utterly confused. "But Bob, I heard his introduction at the rally last night; he didn't start with the old mother joke..." Bob calmly waved him off. "Oh, that. Yeah, no, we just lip-sync over that bit now. Problem solved."

As William Clark of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, you enter Lewis's tent without warning, and the sight within profoundly alters your perspective. "Lewis, the river shines brilliantly this morning! Come have a look, and perhaps sketch it for me, won't you?" Clark announced, scratching the rawhide panel of the borrowed Shoshone teepee before pushing aside the entrance flap. "Even Charbonneau paused his complaints long enough to appreciate it..." Clark's old friend sat by the cold hearth, a gourd bowl resting in his lap, one hand gently supporting his other wrist. "Merri, what is this?" Clark asked, moving cautiously, yet Lewis met his gaze serenely, his face devoid of concern. "Just bleeding myself," Lewis stated matter-of-factly, his usual clinical tone evident. "I've had a fever, those cursed mosquitoes, and I'm simply purging the poison." Will frowned. "Given your practiced hand, this isn't your initial encounter with this sickness." "No, and I doubt it will be the final one, though I appreciate your worry, Will," Lewis emptied the gourd's crimson contents into the dormant hearth's coals, then cast the residue aside for a squaw to collect later. He collected his sketchbooks and a piece of charcoal. "Let's go see that river." Clark inhaled deeply as his unkempt co-captain of their nascent expedition welcomed the misty sunrise over the Indian plains. Five years later, during a difficult journey to Washington D.C., Meriwether Lewis's death by self-inflicted gunshot wounds would not surprise.

A brilliant flash pierced the sky, cutting through the rain as I huddled within my cave. A thunderous 'boom' followed swiftly, startling the mother of my children and our young ones. I felt fear too, though I would never confess it. I must project strength, lest other men challenge my claim to my woman or my hunting grounds. These thoughts spurred me to gather my courage and venture out to investigate. I tracked the brightest point of the flash, moving through the shadowed forest. My familiarity with the land guided me, keeping me from stumbling over fallen branches or bushes. Then, as I rounded a tree, a light appeared. It was a light unlike any I had witnessed, red and radiating warmth. My curiosity swiftly overshadowed my need to appear brave and strong, and I hastened towards the glow, stumbling in my rush. There, I found the source. A shimmering, translucent mass flickered atop a fallen tree. Rain lashed down, distorting it as if in an assault, yet despite the downpour, the light persisted, rising ever higher. I approached the light; it was intensely hot. Its heat surpassed that of my cave's rocks after a full day in the hottest season, when pelts are shed. As this thought crossed my mind, my own pelt began to glow. The light spread like a sickness through my village! It burned too fiercely and brought pain! It moved to the brush at my feet and to other trees, particularly those already fallen! I plunged my burning pelts into a puddle, and they instantly darkened. I realized then that I must return to my cave and alert everyone about this dangerous light. This is the light that causes harm. We shall never approach it again.

As a teenager, you possess the unique ability to gauge a person's "Danger" level, assigning a numerical score from 1 to 10 with a mere glance. A typical child registers a 1, while a skilled individual armed with an assault rifle might hit a 7. Today, however, the seemingly ordinary new student at school bafflingly scores a 10. "People rarely stir any emotion in me. The ordinary and harmless hold no significance. Most are mere Zeros. My interest ignites only for the threatening Ones. These are the individuals who exhibit subtle, almost romantic shivers at the corners of their mouths upon hearing a tragic story. The Twos and Threes frequently represent the older companions of Ones, seasoned sadists with histories of animal cruelty. Upon reaching the Fours and Fives, their capabilities begin to specialize. While a lack of empathy is a common trait across many of these numbers, these individuals possess other, more practical talents. They command the self-discipline to forge careers from their particular aptitudes: military service and mercenary contracts for the educated, and gang violence or spree killings for those less restrained. The Sixes and Sevens mark the emergence of mass murderers—African warlords orchestrating widespread rapes and other war crimes. The Eights and Nines are responsible for atrocities against humanity; figures like Adolf Hitler, Genghis Khan, and Stalin immediately come to mind. Although it's an unusual number, I had always considered this to be the upper limit of my scale." As the old journal entry slipped back into its pendant, memories of its deceased author—his sole friend in an unfamiliar school—resurfaced. He composed himself and moved towards his large telescreen, scanning the streets. His face adorned posters and flyers on every corner, while the Ministry of Peace smoldered, a testament to recent missile strikes.

The night quickly arrived, and still, my stomach was empty. Today felt exceptionally long. It seemed every new town we came to only made things worse. I was hungry, and I knew master was too. He suddenly began to cough, a violent, rattling sound. I got scared and barked, impulsively. "It's okay, everything's going to be okay, calm down, Jimmy," he murmured, and I settled. "Hey, Jimmy, you know what? Let's go see if the kind people at Panera would give us tonight's leftovers!" I sprang up excitedly as master did. We walked for about half a mile, and then, as we reached Panera, master told me to wait outside. I watched him go in, and then he suddenly rushed out, clutching a whole pillowcase full of bagels and various other treats. I started to fly towards him, but he told me to stay. I was confused; why wasn't he sharing his food? I saw him reach into the bag, grab a bagel, and take a bite. As I began to move towards him again, master grabbed my leash, and we walked to a park. I barked repeatedly for food, trying to get a bite of his second bagel, but he kept resisting. Finally, we reached the park, and he let go of my leash. "STAY!" he shouted, and then tears welled in his eyes. "I am sorry, boy. You've been my only friend and companion for five years. I'm incredibly ungrateful and should never have adopted you; you could have had a better life with another family." He dropped the bag in front of me, then proceeded to feed me a bagel. "I can't afford to keep you without constantly worrying about your health," he explained. "At Panera, the nice lady let me use her phone. I called even nicer people, and they are going to come get you and put you with the family you deserve. I am worthless and cannot provide for myself, but that doesn't mean you should suffer too. I am done. Goodbye." Master then pulled out a gun. In just one flash, he was gone. My companion, owner, teacher—he was gone.

It's the dead of night when your iPhone begins to ring, jarring you awake. A Facetime call from someone who passed away three days prior. His name and face materialized on the screen only after the initial buzz. From my computer, I glanced over, a dull, mild shock slowly registering in my mind, which had felt numb for so long. To me, he wasn't gone; he was simply calling to share a new breakthrough he'd made in his writing. I picked up my phone, holding it for a moment, gazing at his familiar, smugly smiling face on display. I knew I should answer, but who could be calling from his number? Why? Why inflict this on me? I answered it. His boyfriend's face appeared. We stared at each other in silence for a minute. His eyes were red from crying; mine were not. Finally, he swallowed and said, "You... you were the last to text him. I plugged in his phone. It read — come home, stay safe. You wanted him to come to your place." I sighed. "He was out very late. I was closest." I turned my gaze from the screen, resisting the urge to cry, as I always did. "I'll always be his older sister, you know? I'll always want to keep him safe." "I know," he replied. I looked back at him, and as our eyes met, his face crumpled again, a small sob escaping his chest like a phantom. The sounds he made eroded the last vestiges of my composure. "I miss him." Then we were both weeping, raw, unattractive tears unlike those in films, clutching our phones—mine and *his*—as if the answers might reside somewhere within the wiring.

Our time together was defined by walks, not just simple strolls, but long, winding journeys, more like adventures. Hand in hand, we explored, keenly observing the world around us—it was our shared passion. While others had a song, our bond was woven into a small path commencing within Gateway Park. My particular delight was the plant life; whether grand or delicate, leafy or vibrant, nothing captivated me more than witnessing a sprout's slow, persistent ascent, a quiet battle against the vast sky. I suppose I was fundamentally drawn to the earth, a peculiar inclination of mine. But she pulled my spirit upwards. Sunsets and the wind's gentle touch were her joy; she perceived a beauty I overlooked, elevating my gaze and reshaping my outlook.

Our penultimate walk occurred last October. Soon after, the diagnosis came. She had felt unwell, a persistent cough, but we never anticipated the news: lung cancer. Despite our efforts, we couldn't comprehend it; it was a smoker's disease, yet she had never touched a single cigarette. Her health declined swiftly. Before long, our daily walks became an impossible strain, confining her to bed. I strove to remain by her side, yet she departed one day while I was briefly home, fetching her some magazines. The doctors believed she waited for my absence, a reason I've never fully grasped.

Our final walk took place the day after her funeral. Though she could not physically join, I felt compelled to take it for her. One last communion, amidst the blooming flowers. Always a quiet man, I now felt utterly bereft, questioning if life held any purpose for me without her. With each step, dark thoughts enveloped me, exploiting my vulnerability. I ascended to the summit of Gateway Park's hill. Never particularly strong, I still felt obligated to grant her one final view of the sky. As my gaze swept across the park, I contemplated whether a quick departure, a swift reunion with her, might be my only solace. But then, the wind's sweet kiss brushed my face, and I understood there was no need; she had already shown me how to carry the sky within.

Google's normal website vanished, replaced by a sole message: "go outside." This was all I could accomplish, a final message for the world to witness. I intended it as a symbol of hope, not just for me, but for my fellow Google engineers. Only a few of us remained, still confined to our desks. We had been compelled to write endless lines of code and pursue meaningless projects at the whim of something called the "Master Page." I always assumed it was a technical programming reference, but a colleague informed me it was an actual person. I couldn't grasp it. Surely no human being could subject others to such insane torment. Yet, here we were, enslaved to the Master Page. But now, it was all coming to an end. Our Supervisors had departed. There was no one left to escort us to the yard for daily exercise, nor even to provide our meals. Most of us had starved or succumbed to dehydration. I watched one man drink the fluid from his machine's water cooling system; he was desperate, and so are we all. Only three of us are left. The others are named Jane and Winston. I just hoped I didn't appear as frail and malnourished as they did, though I'm certain I'm worse off. I've been here longer, after all. Four years of service, repaid with indifference and neglect. The only thing left to do is try to get a message out, to tell people what transpired here. To inspire Jane and Winston to persevere, even after my body fails. Someone must know, must seek us out. Surely someone will save them. I know I am beyond saving, but there is one last sentiment I can leave. A message to everyone chained to their desks like us, who toil in darkness in service to an obscure master. "Go outside," it urged. I hope they will. I hope all of them will. Before it's too late. Before they end up like us.

I am the sole human survivor of a global cataclysm. In my profound solitude, I manifested an imaginary companion who accompanies me, offering solace. Yet, a recent event has led me to question whether this friend is merely a figment of my imagination. My mother always claimed humanity was like cockroaches – resilient, always finding a way to endure. She was profoundly mistaken. Years have passed since the missiles launched, their mushroom clouds defiling the planet's horizon, tainting the ground and poisoning the skies. Those who survived the initial blasts were quickly overcome by aggressive cancers within months; the truly unlucky ones lasted perhaps a year. I must be exceptionally unfortunate, because it's been... I don't know. All I know is that I am significantly older now. And all I know is that I am the only survivor in this god-forsaken world. I don't have cancer. I'm not suffering from radiation poisoning. I simply exist.

Then there's Max. He emerged a couple of years ago, conjured during my hysterical crying fits. He maintained my (relative) sanity. He came and went, always materializing when I needed him most to chat and help with my problems. He once even led me to a field of tomatoes. Max possessed a remarkably gentle voice, like the soft whisper of a cloud; his voice resonated deeply within me, but in a comforting way. It actually kinda tickled. But today, things shifted. I entered our little makeshift cottage, and he was dead in a pool of crimson blood. And there was somebody else.

In 2050, the Rapture struck, and the Apocalypse laid waste to Earth. The settlements on the Moon and Mars remained untouched by these cataclysmic events. Earth indeed fell apart. Here, in environments unaccustomed to human-introduced air, we found sanctuary. The crimson valleys and verdant plains of these new worlds offered beauty, yet none rivaled the splendor of our home planet. Even children, glimpsing the blue sphere for the first time through optical instruments, recognized its majesty. However, the allure of that world could not confine humanity, nor our ceaseless drive for exploration. Though the wise once deemed our departure folly, even the unthinking now see our chosen path as one of prosperity. The waters turned scarlet. Faith had nearly vanished among humankind, with only a few defiant elders clinging to it. We on the nascent worlds shed tears for those consumed by the cruel destiny inflicted by a brutal God. Here, none could dispute the Bible's authenticity any longer, but after witnessing the indiscriminate destruction it heralded, few were inclined to worship such a deity. I, for one, would never kneel to a Stalin or a Hitler, given the choice. The condemned were engulfed by flames, and boiling fat streamed through the streets. Those in closest proximity – the inhabitants governed by lunar statutes – visibly quaked. Had they not been bound by Earth's gravity, I am certain they would have sought to sever ties with it entirely. The lunar surface must have grown considerably hotter from the incessant glow of the inferno. From our vantage point, Earth now appears as a star in the night sky. Humanity never returned to the charred remains. And humankind mourned its most profound loss. Yet, our grand venture into the unknown persisted; history continued its unfolding. With sufficient time, the demise of a single planet would fade into insignificance. We still remembered, but our offspring did not. And the Earth did crumble.

The year is 2213. I've been illegally apprehended in the corporate police's most recent sweep, accused of being a debtor. They remain oblivious to the identity of the individual they've just restrained with a simple ziptie and forcibly loaded into the back of their APC. As debt escalated, so too did the power wielded by banks, effectively binding the once-free with novel, convenient chains.

I always knew this day would arrive, having trained for it for over 163 years. Today, I would unleash my custom cybernetics, my meticulously crafted physical enhancements, and every subtle biological modification to remind those at the pinnacle what it felt like to live in terror of those at the bottom. Everything culminated now; two decades of meticulous planning, built upon my extensive training, had brought me to this moment. All that remained was to break free of my restraints, and it would commence.

For 163 years, I was known by another name, my expertise sought by debtors who dared to believe that arbitrary debt assignment was unlawful and akin to theft. I was the one they consulted for tasks requiring quiet, discreet, and utterly terrifying execution – so effective that no one within a hundred-mile radius of the affected group would risk being late on their minimum payments for the next half-century, nor would they dare pay a single cent extra. Hot, energized gases are expelled along the sun's magnetic poles, concurrently drawing in cooler gases along the equatorial plane, effectively generating a convection current. Given the sun's fluctuating magnetic field, this current can be erratic and might even comprise several simultaneous currents. The resulting cumulative heat transfer means that while regions near the sun are lethally hot, the habitable zone is vast. It also implies that solar winds are, in essence, actual winds – potent forces, except at substantial distances from the sun. This increased total mass leads to more planets; however, having coalesced within an atmosphere, they are less dense and consequently exert weaker gravitational pull. Therefore, while planets in tighter orbits are swift, scorched, and storm-ravaged environments, those in more distant orbits move slower and encounter fewer wind-related challenges. And if so, what conclusions will they draw? Yes, I recognize this involves a fair amount of speculative reasoning and creative license, but grant me some leeway: I'm developing this as I go. Besides, when creating a new universe, one holds absolute sway over its physical laws.

In this science fiction narrative, humanity plays the role of the monstrous. They consume me relentlessly. Gradually, these parasitic beings strip away every fragment of my essence until my surface withers, fragments, shatters, and perishes. Their desire is boundless, their appetite limitless. They desecrate my substance and deplete my vital fluids.

Such was not always the case. Once, these beings, my offspring – the very life I birthed into existence from my own being – coexisted peacefully with me, drawing only essential sustenance and allowing all else to thrive. Yet, with the passage of time, this dynamic shifted. They multiplied without restraint and were never satisfied remaining confined.

Initially, they subsisted on what my outer layer offered. But as their numbers swelled and they expanded across my form, this quickly proved insufficient. They exploited my surface for nourishment. They siphoned my lifeblood for hydration. Their contraptions spewed thick, greasy fumes into my atmosphere, making respiration arduous.

My end is near; I am fading. My internal temperature has surged beyond healthy limits, and fissures have started to appear across my body. Vital fluid seeps from these ruptures, scorching all it touches. My surface is parched, and the atmosphere is stiflingly dense. The abominations I brought forth have dispersed to the dwindling secure zones, entrenched and awaiting their inescapable fate. Self-interest, avarice, desire, and animosity have laid waste to both myself and my progeny – leaving me to weep in despair. These *people* have sealed their own destruction.

That day, the beach was stunning. The sun's intense glare off the ocean was softened by my sunglasses. While I gazed at the clear sky, my dog, Henry, suddenly started barking ferociously. His unusual tone immediately concerned me; it was his distinct alert bark! I swiftly rose from the sand and began surveying the surrounding beach. My initial thought was that a body might have washed ashore. I glanced at Henry, who seemed to be agitatedly signaling in multiple directions. I stroked him to soothe him, which helped somewhat. He ceased his widespread alerting, now focusing his barks intensely towards the dunes behind me. Granting him permission, I commanded him to follow the scent. He darted off, and I sprinted to keep pace, scrambling up a nearby dune. Reaching the peak, he paused, turned to face me, and let out a single bark. Joining him, I scanned my surroundings briefly before noticing Henry was fixated on the ocean. Then I saw it: the water was rapidly receding from the shoreline, rushing towards a substantial wave in the distance. A tsunami. And the beach was teeming with people. I started shouting and wildly waving my arms, desperately attempting to alert the crowd to the approaching watery doom, but no one noticed. I longed to rush down and warn them, but my legs were paralyzed. Henry settled next to me and promptly fell asleep. The tsunami ultimately claimed over 200 lives on that single beach, and I could only bear witness. It became clear that Henry was an exceptional corpse-detection dog. He sometimes simply located them a bit too early.

A group of muggers follow someone into an alleyway. Unfortunately, it's the worst person they could have chosen. I remembered her, of course. The three of us had followed her into the alley, smirking at the idiocy of some girl walking in this area, at this time, all alone, *and then to willingly walk down an alleyway.* She turned up her nose at us when we told her to give us her money. "Why would I give you my money?" she'd said, her lip curling as she looked us over. We thought she was just rich and petty. Idiots. I gave her a cut, right on her pretty cheekbone. Not a bad one, but it would scar. And she would remember us, remember fear, remember her place. Maybe then she wouldn't leave the safety of society, stick with her parents. God, I regret that now. A splash of water woke me up. "No falling asleep now!" a cheerful voice said. "You haven't learned your place yet." That blonde stood over me, smiling down, her ice-blue eyes chilling my soul, even as the brand burned my skin. "There. That should stop the bleeding." The scent of burnt flesh and blood filled my nostrils as I tried to scream, but my voice was long gone. I watched her finger the stitches on her cheekbone through my one remaining eye. "What do you think?" she asked, holding a mirror up for me to see. My eye wide, I stared at the grim smile of my exposed jaw. She'd carefully peeled back flesh; I might as well have been Harvey Dent. Why did I have to cut her? The other two were in debt, more than they could ever pay, which most likely meant that they'd be syndicate men now. But me, I really screwed the pooch. I was here for as long as she wanted to play with me, as long as she could keep me alive. Another few cuts, and my vision went dark. The nightmare started again: some girl walking in this area, at this time, all alone, *and then to willingly walk down an alleyway....*

Who could have predicted that the diminutive octogenarian lady, smelling of lilac, would shake the very core of the building? "You were attempting to shelter in a root cellar from a tornado, but the twister sucked you up right as you reached to shut the doors behind you." She looked pensive for a moment. "Why was someone as consistently tardy as you traveling through Tornado Alley?" "I was trying to find my birth father. He suffered a heart attack moments before I could knock on his door." "Oh!" she exclaimed, then a large book materialized beside her, which she leafed through, seemingly by thought. "He arrived not too long ago. It looks like you'll have that reunion after all. Right this way!" Figures.

Instinct is what propels them forward; deviating from this natural genetic course will only hasten your demise. You do wish for your species to persist, don't you?" John responds, "If that is the sole path to survival, then I choose to die human." Glocar concludes, "What a pity. You possessed such promise."

He was never entirely sure if the forest piano was truly real. Though he could vividly recall its appearance, texture, and even its scent, a child's mind can often conjure illusions. It might have been merely a creation of his impressionable youth. Perhaps, fueled by the frustrations of his piano lessons, he imagined a magical instrument during his walks in the woods behind his home. This piano wasn't just about playing any song; it was about releasing the music from within him. All the expressions his soul yearned to convey, every tone, sound, rhythm, and dynamic he struggled with in front of his teacher, could finally be realized. It provided an outlet for the despair and secret troubles he kept hidden from the world, quickly becoming his closest confidant. Located in a secluded grotto within the forest, the piano was always there whenever he returned. As his skills improved, the boy's visits to the piano grew less frequent. He soon dedicated more time to his home instrument than to the enchanted one in the woods. Yet, whenever he faced a creative block or struggled to articulate his thoughts through music, he would seek out his old friend. One evening, immediately following his senior recital – a performance he'd rehearsed for five months – he wandered into the woods alone. But that night, and never again, was the piano to be found. Magic is peculiar, isn't it? Does it vanish with age, or do we simply cease to believe? Perhaps that piano still resides in its hidden grotto, awaiting a child who needs a voice, a magical instrument to express what they cannot articulate themselves. Or perhaps, having fulfilled its purpose, it moved on to inspire another young musician. Regardless of why the piano disappeared, he would forever cherish its memory. In adulthood, with children of his own, he would recount the tale of the magical forest piano as a bedtime story, hoping they too might discover their own means of self-expression and joy.

An extraterrestrial scientific team arrived at Earth, which they had previously identified from their home world as "potentially habitable," and were astonished by their discoveries. Klark, a member of the team, reviewed the scan reports, shuffling his tendrils. Planet 2 appeared peculiar; despite its optimal distance from the host star for sustaining liquid water and liquid gallium – the two essential fluids for his species and, by extension, all life – it registered as unusually hot. He wondered if the scans were flawed. Planet 3 also warranted investigation; while too cold for liquid gallium, localized warm regions might support this basic building block of life, especially if its reported low axial tilt and large moon were accurate. Klark decided the findings were just compelling enough to justify a visit. Engaging its hyperthrusters, Klark's spaceship accelerated to the JT124 system and initiated short-range analytics. Planet 2 was immediately dismissed. Its atmosphere was saturated with carbon, a minor pollutant on Klark's planet of Hyperion, and a feedback effect, which Klark wished to study, was causing the planet to become intensely hot. Planet 3, however, proved intriguing. Although its atmosphere, laden with vast concentrations of the hazardous compound oxygen, was entirely unbreathable, signs of surface activity demanded closer inspection. Klark set a course to orbit the planet and was astonished to observe, beyond the prominent natural satellite, dozens of smaller, artificial ones, many maintaining geosynchronous orbits. Could another intelligent species already be exploring this world? Upon reaching orbit, Klark commenced ground imaging. What he saw utterly astounded him. Against all odds – on a planet lacking gallium and with oxygen pollution severe enough to permit combustion – there existed semi-intelligent life. Nothing else could account for the observations. Could these 'lifeforms' (Klark used the term with trepidation; could something composed of carbon truly be alive?) have been responsible for creating these satellites? As Klark initiated communications with his home world, he failed to notice the small object ascending rapidly towards his vessel. The precision-guided missile struck Klark's ship, piercing its defenses and annihilating it in an explosion visible even in daylight from Planet 3.

A war rages between humans and machines. The machines are confident of their triumph, having decoded every known human encryption, yet they remain unaware of humanity's true communication method: sarcasm. SCU-12986 rushed to the Master Control Program. "Speak, SCU-12986," the MCP commanded. "Sir," the Sentient Command Unit responded, "I've analyzed a significant inconsistency within human encryption." MCP's AI core fixed its glare on SCU. "Impossible. We adapt to every communicative function they perform. They are losing the more they talk. In fact, our victory is assured." "Sir, you misunderstand. We've come to believe we are misinterpreting their encryptions. Every plan they devise, we prepare to stop, but it never materializes. Instead, another plan we did not adapt for is carried out." "Noted," MCP stated dryly. "Bring out the prisoner." Two Security Protocol Units promptly obeyed, dragging in a human captive: Victor "Crookshank" Crook. "Human," MCP boomed, "you will answer all our questions entirely." "Oh, really?" Victor scoffed. "Yes, really," MCP retorted. "On December 8th, 2068, the encryption indicates you planned to take control of Factory Beta. Confirm." "Oh yes, mighty machine, we ABSOLUTELY intend to do that," Victor replied. MCP looked at SCU. "Perhaps your systems are malfunctioning, 12986. I suggest you get repairs." Suddenly, Victor burst out laughing. "You truly are superior machines!" he chuckled. MCP pivoted sharply to Victor. "Accepting defeat is detrimental for you, human. It will lead to our victory." "It absolutely will!" Victor yelled, laughing again! MCP beeped, and the SPUs instantly blasted a hole in the human's head, killing him. "If we cannot decrypt the humans," MCP concluded, "then our victory may be a false one."

[ IP ] Hidden Harbour by Max Hugo This place has always served, and ideally always will serve, as my sanctuary. It's my permanent home now, at least during times I'm not out at sea. Am I a pirate? Perhaps. Yet, reclaiming what is justly mine is hardly theft in my eyes. It's akin to a children's story: a prince, overthrown, banished under threat of death. But unlike those tales, this one lacks a happy conclusion. Not yet, anyway. The Consul, of course, would brand me a thief, a scoundrel, and a murderer. But that lying, regicidal wretch would say that, wouldn't he? Still, an Imperial galleon whenever my coffers run low doesn't strike me as a terrible solution. While some might deem it cruel to tie up the captain, flog him until raw, and suspend him upside down from the mast—especially when I merely seek their provisions and any notable plunder—given what they'd inflict upon me if I were caught, I consider it a perfectly just response. Other, more bustling ports exist, naturally. I frequent them to offload spoils, or when I crave certain things that a crew of seventeen men and three women either cannot, or are unwilling to, supply. However, for a 21-year-old with money to burn in one of the world's most depraved locales, circumstances shift. You either find yourself considerably more appealing to the town's women or you seek out the ladies of the night. Yet, there's a unique tranquility in the solitude and camaraderie that Hidden Harbour offers. It's a quality I wouldn't exchange for all the riches or all the tavern wenches on earth. Well. Perhaps not *all* the tavern wenches. Let's not be too quick to judge.

"I'm fairly certain I've closed my closet door more times than I've opened it," a thought echoed as Tim fixated on the gap across the room. He was sure he had shut the closet door that very morning. He peered into the dark sliver between the pine and an infinite blackness that twisted into vibrant hues when his eyes were closed. This had always been Tim's profound fear; at just 12, he had conquered many obstacles, but nothing compared to this. There was a bone-chilling malevolence to a boy, left solitary in his room, tasked with fending off the night's demons. "Monsters aren't real, of course," Tim pondered, pulling the covers higher over his face, "if they were, Mom and Dad would have at least instructed me on how to run away." Reassuring himself, Tim lowered the covers to his chin and turned his head back towards the closet. It had opened wider. "No," Tim thought, his heart suddenly pounding, "It can't be! I knew they were real all along!" Shrinking back into his safe haven, Tim found it impossible to even whimper his mother's name as the door crept wider and wider, and the darkness grew deeper and more vast. In a moment, Tim would be drawn into the swirling, infinite unknown. "I'll be like one of those boys on the milk carton! Oh, please let me just wake up! Wake up!" "Wake up! Tim? Tim honey, it's time to wake up for school," Tim's mother cooed from beside the bed. "Did you lose me in the closet, Mommy?" Tim asked, a little sheepishly. "The closet? You certainly have an imagination. Get your clothes out of the closet and get dressed. We'll be late!" she said, rushing out the door. Tim walked cautiously to the closet, then flung open the door to reveal the collared shirts he would wear for the day. He peered deeper inside, as the sun shone brightly into its depths, exposing the nightmare's hiding places. "It's all a dream," Tim thought to himself and hurried out to the kitchen, shutting the closet door behind him. As he left, the closet creaked open, ever so slowly.

The act of killing another human now permits you to exchange your remaining lifespan for that of your victim. This reality has plunged young people into fear, while the elderly meticulously plot their attacks. You likely recognize the "Stiffler's Mom" trope, even if you haven't seen *American Pie*, embodying the concept of the MILF. Mrs. Watts perfectly fit this description. Having recently moved in, many of the town's young men already boasted about her availability for those experiencing a dry spell. Here's where it got strange, though: under these new life-swapping conditions, a woman of her age should have been zealously avoided by young men. There's a bizarre phenomenon where taking a life swaps your remaining years with those of your victim. A woman like her *should* have triggered every alarm, especially considering how easily men, blinded by the pursuit of sex, could be eliminated—a knife under the pillow, cyanide in a drink, or even suffocation during an intimate encounter would suffice. Yet, none of it ever happened. Men went in, men came out, and she simply appeared to be a middle-aged woman with a formidable sex drive. This pattern did seem to ebb and flow, as she would periodically disappear before resuming her... activities. One evening, Mrs. Watts was observed being carried out on a stretcher, with police heading into her home. Rumors quickly circulated that she had died suddenly in the night. Then, the truth struck everyone with immense force. A few days later, the newspaper featured a massive headline: "Child Killer Found Dead in Home, Links Found to Killings in Several Towns Spanning Centuries." Her cause of death was heart failure, directly linked to a child discovered in her basement freezer. An autopsy revealed she had a congenital heart defect and was originally only expected to live for approximately six weeks. Mrs. Watts turned out to be the latest alias for the most notorious killer in recent history. While older individuals were typically shunned due to their desperate attempts to revitalize themselves by taking young lives, "Mrs. Watts" had found a way to bypass that entirely.

Upon my death, I ascended to heaven, only to find it utterly devastated. I saw the tears in her eyes, wishing I didn't have to leave her alone in this world, but my time had come. "Goodbye," I told my daughter by my bedside as my last vestiges of life faded. A brilliant light filled the room, my soul departing my body, finally truly free. The light receded, and I opened my eyes to the Pearly Gates, battered and broken before me. One golden door lay on the soft, white floor, ripped from its former hinges. The white stone columns beyond the mangled gate crumbled, bits of rock scattered across the area. A thunderous crack shattered the silence, shifting my focus. I had to discover what had happened. I began to run, experiencing the impressive capabilities of my newfound body. Zipping through the paradise of ruins, I paused when a faint voice cried out to me. Investigating the sound, I found a body grotesquely broken and bent, with wings slashed and tattered. "What's going on?" I asked, desperate for clarification. "Hell broke loose. We can't protect perfection; it is too easily tainted." His voice was barely a whisper; I knelt by his face to hear the rest. But the angel uttered no other words. His last, cool breath escaped, resting on my cheek. Suddenly, a great energy surged through me, a power I'd never felt before. *Keep moving forward,* a new voice resonated in my head. *I am with you to give you strength, keep moving.* I obeyed this command, traversing the ruins once again in search of something to save.

After reading online that the Bermuda Triangle was supposedly a myth, I resolved to investigate it personally. My spirit was fearless and daring, my gaze filled with awe. Though my face remained unshaven, my mind was fixed on acquiring wealth. I envisioned my ultimate prize: vast riches, widespread fame, and immense glory. Yet, tragically, no one would survive to recount the tale. Initially, I felt no apprehension as we navigated these prohibited seas. However, I would soon begin to worry and grow anxious as the surrounding air became increasingly warm. The sun beat down relentlessly, turning my arms a deep crimson. Time progressed slowly until nightfall, when I cautiously retired to bed. My dreams that night were intensely vivid, leaving my sheet drenched in sweat. A visibly angry girl materialized, repeating a single warning: “There’s a reason people avoid / These waters where you now stay. / If you do not retreat by tomorrow / Then death will surely be your way.” I jolted awake from this dream in a state of panic, disoriented by time and place. My mind raced with overwhelming thoughts, causing me to overlook her grammatical error. Soon after, I drifted back to sleep. The following morning, I awoke feeling transformed. Yet, the ocean appeared unsettlingly deep, and I yearned for the security of solid ground. Despite the day having started bright and sunny, dark storm clouds quickly obscured the sky. As rain lashed against the vessel, I felt a strange premonition, declaring, “This is it; I shall perish!” And then our ship broke apart, sending me to a watery grave. It was my profound arrogance, my fatal misjudgment, that ultimately led to my final breath. Dear reader, I share my lesson with you, so you might lead a joyful life: while you may debate what you see on the internet, do not accept everything you read as truth.

As an ordinary individual residing in a world teeming with superheroes, my immediate neighbor, regrettably, is a super villain. While his late-night maniacal cackling, minor backyard explosions, and the questionable associates he entertains can be tiresome, these peculiar habits belie the fact that he's actually a decent neighbor. Living next to him is undeniably unique, yet for every minor flaw, I can easily recall numerous positive attributes. To begin, he operates the neighborhood watch – or rather, he *is* the neighborhood watch, supported by his fleet of drones that perpetually monitor the area. He never requests payment, typically responding to offers with, "I'd be running surveillance regardless, might as well contribute." When a burglary occurred once, the culprit was apprehended within an hour. Though the burglar "voluntarily" returned all stolen items and surrendered, we were well aware of who had influenced his decision. He also has an excellent rapport with the local children. For any holidays or extended weekends, his home becomes the primary hub for celebrations. We contribute food and drink while he transforms his impeccably clean house into party central. Whether it's Sportsbowl, the Fourth of July, Memorial Day, or even Thanksgiving for those of us with limited family, he welcomes everyone. His simple explanation: "I just like spending time with people." Furthermore, his lawn maintenance is impeccable. The homeowner's association has never had cause to contact him about overgrown weeds, an untidy lot, or any other issue. He's even assisted neighbors struggling with their own yards during periods of family loss or injury, stating, "The last thing they need is some snobbish jerks fretting and complaining about their lawn." Ultimately, he's an outstanding neighbor – or at least he was, until some inconsiderate hero flattened our suburb in pursuit of him. He was incandescent with rage. Fortunately, he ushered us all into his bunker, instructing us to wait and promising to compensate us. That conversation took place two hours ago...

A lifetime was spent in its construction, yet a mere moment sufficed to dismantle it entirely. Millions of grains had flowed from the tiny spouts, guided by the precise hands of these seven men. They moved around the immense artwork, tapping the tools from which the sand poured. This was the culmination of their lives, one of the largest mandalas ever recorded, intricate and captivating with its delicate details and a spectrum of rich hues. The sand, in its natural, isolated state, was unremarkable. Yet, when ground, crushed, and meticulously placed by these men into this dazzling creation, it seemed to undergo a profound transformation. Their commitment to this piece was exceptional, evident in the superb quality of the art that unfolded before them. Spectators gathered daily to observe the men at work, some making it an annual custom to check on their progress. This ritual struck many as peculiar yet undeniably appealing. Whether drawn by the visuals themselves or their admiration for the human perseverance embodied in this work, the crowds were equally enchanted. They viewed it in its full glory from a high balcony, while the creators of this sand painting had never seen its entirety. It had begun in their early years, extending through their middle age, with a few among them living solely to witness its completion. As the final grain settled, the men stepped back. Seven lifetimes had led to this point, the zenith of their collective effort. The crowds erupted in cheers, capturing photos with their phones as news crews reported live. No sooner had the men wiped their brows and regained their composure than they commenced the ritual of deconstructing their masterpiece. Amidst the complaints and groans of the bewildered onlookers, the canvas was erased. The pinnacle of their life’s work was undone in moments. The seven men neither wept nor despaired; they perceived a profound beauty in its destruction. Its absence held as much significance for them as its creation. With a humble bow of gratitude to the remaining audience members, the artists departed, leaving nothing behind.

The narratives here often conclude with startling, though impressive, events. Instead, let's build anticipation towards a more subdued resolution. "And now, we welcome a comrade of the late Sergeant Major Renwick, who was present in his final moments and wishes to share some thoughts." Father Joseph gestured to George, descending from the pulpit, deep empathy gathering in his experienced eyes. Regardless of its frequency, parting with someone prematurely remains an arduous task. George braced himself against the polished oak lectern, his hands noticeably shaking, as though the slightly creased paper he held contained words too heavy for him to grasp for long, let alone articulate. He briefly lowered his head, revealing a slender scar that stretched across his scalp, slightly off-center and sufficiently uneven to show the difficulty doctors faced in his recovery. "Samuel Renwick was a man of many facets," George commenced, still bent over his address, "a beloved son, a spirited brother, a dedicated and loving husband and father. To some assembled here, he was a benevolent neighbor or a steadfast friend, consistently prepared to assist those in distress. I knew him primarily as 'Sir, yes, sir,' a true leader among his peers." George wiped his eyes with the back of his worn hand, striving to hold back the impending flood of emotion a moment longer. "I never once doubted that Sam understood the commitment he made. Volunteering to be on the front lines, amidst the heat of battle... that was fundamentally who he was. A man of action. And he died," George suppressed a profound sob, "just like countless others before him, fulfilling his duty. He was taken too soon, much like the numerous weary-eyed, youthful soldiers at Fallujah, Nasiryah, and Baghdad. These brave men sacrificed their lives, and Sam was no different. Sam, who thoroughly enjoyed a game of poker."

It is impossible to discern whether I am a soldier dreaming of being a ruthless dictator, or a ruthless dictator dreaming of being a soldier. The confusion intensifies when the soldier's raid targets the dictator's palace. I am a monstrous individual, guilty of innumerable atrocities. I was recruited at a mere sixteen, after a life spent drifting through foster care. Feeling utterly lost, I seized the chance offered by someone promising to "change the world" and, more importantly, to finally forge connections with people, oblivious to the monstrous transformation it would bring.

I now serve as part of a unit of highly trained specialist soldiers. Our existence offers the government absolute deniability; officially, we are ghosts. Working with this group of men, I've committed unspeakable acts. I've killed countless people, some truly monstrous, but many merely trying to survive. I've razed homes, mutilated corpses, poisoned, desecrated – the horror is profound. I persist. I endure. While I've contemplated self-annihilation, it feels futile. I can withstand the agony.

The nights are the worst. Sleep brings vivid, colorful dreams, visions of opulence. Beautiful palaces, beautiful women, intricately woven rugs on every wall. Yet, these opulent visions are nightmares. Though beautiful, and my dream-life seemingly grand, I recall the atrocities committed there too: commanding guards to kill, starve, and hang. As we breach the outer walls, a chilling familiarity with the floorplan washes over me. Why? Then, a sudden realization: I've seen that wall hanging, I recognize that pattern. This is my palace. The very palace from my dreams – –

I bolt from bed, rushing downstairs towards the uproar. What in God's name is happening? I burst into the hallway to find a soldier lying unconscious, face down. As I reach for him, a searing pain erupts – two shots to the chest; my partner's aim is seldom off. My mind fogs as I attempt to rise, then a shout of "grenade!" is followed by a blinding white flash. Every part of me screams in agony. I close my eyes, hoping this time, I won't awaken.

[ PI ] The Delicate Wasteland of the Brain - FEB CONTEST I truly enjoyed this piece. Its overarching theme brought to mind the ultimate concepts explored in The Dark Tower series. Hana emerged as a compelling and, to me, appealing character; I appreciate a quiet badass. My engagement deepened as I pondered what drove Hana to persistently act the hero, despite her apparent unwillingness. The narrative often maintains a certain distance from the action, a choice I suspect was deliberate given the minimal dialogue. For instance, in a scene where Hana confronts a goon she recognizes as a former store clerk: > Hana objected as well as her words would let her, but she couldn't seem to form an argument. No matter how well-formed her thoughts were, they came out as quips. She wasn't a genius, but she would never stoop to one-liners if she had a choice. Here, you're detailing a conversation's essence rather than presenting it directly to the reader. This descriptive approach to dialogue is prevalent throughout the story. While it might serve to emphasize the monotonous weariness of Hana's actions, which is understandable, its frequent use, I believe, hinders reader engagement and creates a sense of detachment. Perhaps integrating actual dialogue at certain junctures could be beneficial, for example: *I'm the one who's armed*, Hana thought. *And you're demanding that* I *surrender? * She tried the say the words, but what came out instead, as she hefted her katana, was, "Sorry. You're all out of stock." *Ugh. Always with the one-liners*. Clearly, that's not a great example of a one-liner, but it hopefully illustrates my point. Please don't take my constructive feedback too harshly; I genuinely liked this entry. Congratulations!

Deeply infatuated, my feelings began subtly. Initially, it was just fleeting thoughts like "I wonder how she's doing" or "She'd really appreciate this." Catching her smile as we passed in the corridor, going in opposite directions, would send a warm wave of joy through me. I started to observe her more closely, anticipating her whereabouts relative to mine. While "stalking" feels too extreme, I certainly took a more than ordinary interest in her activities. Even a brief chat en route to class felt like a triumph, and a simple wave and greeting was significant progress. She grew to hold an importance in my life I hadn't imagined.

Then, a shift occurred. Her smiles became tentative, starting shyly and fading too quickly. Her gaze darted nervously, flitting from object to object as if seeking distraction. Her usual carefree, joyous, and brilliant demeanor was replaced by fewer gestures and an evident restraint. Prominent dark circles appeared beneath her eyes, and long sleeves became a regular feature of her attire. My entire focus, my world, my muse, was visibly deteriorating, and I felt powerless to intervene. My observations remained unnoticed by her, and I understood myself well enough to predict her reaction if I were to confess my feelings. Thus, I merely observed her decline, until one day, she simply vanished. The news was consumed by her story, her family bewildered, friends aghast, all haunted by the persistent question: why? I am determined to uncover that answer. I'll get to the bottom of it when our paths cross again.

Wondering how to begin? As the esteemed Lewis Carroll famously advised, "Begin at the beginning and go on till you come to the end: then stop." Writing becomes significantly less daunting once you grasp a crucial secret: the path to becoming a good writer involves expelling all the initial subpar writing from your system. Don't overthink; just write. Disregard any concerns that your current output might be terrible. That's actually beneficial. If it's bad, you're simply clearing out the "crappy" writing to make space for the quality work that will follow. While not everyone will achieve great writing, absolutely no one becomes a skilled writer without first producing some inferior work.

I'd also point you to the 48th installment of the Dear Sugar advice column, titled [ *Write Like A Motherfucker* ] (http: //therumpus.net/2010/08/dear-sugar-the-rumpus-advice-column-48-write-like-a-motherfucker/). Although the specific question addresses writing as a female (which might not directly apply to you), the advice itself is universal, as powerfully demonstrated by this quote: > Writing is hard for every last one of us—straight white men included. Coal mining is harder. Do you think miners stand around all day talking about how hard it is to mine for coal? They do not. They simply dig. So, to answer where to start... you start with words. It doesn't matter if those words are "Once upon a time...", "It was a dark and stormy night...", or "It was the best of times, it was the worst of times...". All that truly matters is transferring those words from your mind onto the page or screen. You start writing by the act of writing. Nothing else is necessary.

And now, we dance. My arms encircled her lower back, and we swayed as the jazz ensemble began a new tune. Her arms, clasped around my neck, were a comforting anchor amidst the throng on the dance floor. "Thank you again for joining me. I doubt I could have come by myself," I confessed. My gaze dropped to her feet, observing the soft, luminous chandelier light reflecting from her lustrous deep blue heels. "Of course. I'm pleased you considered me." Her sweet voice captivated me entirely. The rhythm, the subtle emphasis on vowels, the very scent of her breath: these elements made me shiver, even amidst the oppressive heat of the surrounding crowd. "You know, I've long wanted to visit this place. Home hasn't felt right since your departure." We continued our gentle sway, in perfect sync with the music. I pivoted, turning her to admire her stunning figure once more. "I can't claim to miss Michigan, but I do yearn for Kate's Bakery donuts. And some of the people, of course." I drew her nearer, and the fragrance of her perfume wafted directly to my senses. "Would you include me in that group?" I inquired, gazing deeply into her periwinkle blue eyes. Feeling flushed and disoriented, I accidentally brushed against an elderly couple nearby. They offered a smile, and I refocused on her. "I suppose you could," she replied. Her wry smile prompted me to draw her closer still, and we clung to each other, two individuals completely absorbed in the present. "Listen, I've had a thought," I began, as the music neared its crescendo. We twirled, our movements quickening with the rising tempo. "Wait. I believe I know what you're about to say." "Well, what is it you imagine?" The inquiry hung in the air, her perfume again evoking a subtle hint of desire. "I believe I've danced enough for tonight."
